block.p: EAST VILLAGE Shakespeare and Euripides Come to Life in the Park

The Blunt Theater Company's Garden Theater Festival continues this week at La Plaza Cultural, a community park and performance space in the East Village. The festival presents alternate performances of ''The Bacchae,'' a Greek tragedy by Euripides, and Shakespeare's ''A Midsummer Night's Dream.''

''The Bacchae,'' adapted by Sheila Morgan, tells the tale of the battle between Dionysus, the Greek god of wine and revelry, and Pentheus, the ruler of Thebes. The script is underscored with pulsating percussion and a chorus of nine women.
EAST VILLAGE Shakespeare and Euripides Come to Life in the Park

The Blunt Theater Company's Garden Theater Festival continues this week at La Plaza Cultural, a community park and performance space in the East Village. The festival presents alternate performances of ''The Bacchae,'' a Greek tragedy by Euripides, and Shakespeare's ''A Midsummer Night's Dream.''

''The Bacchae,'' adapted by Sheila Morgan, tells the tale of the battle between Dionysus, the Greek god of wine and revelry, and Pentheus, the ruler of Thebes. The script is underscored with pulsating percussion and a chorus of nine women.
The production of ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' incorporates an East Village theme that strives to be fast-paced and funky.

''The Bacchae'': Aug. 27, Sept. 1, 3, 8, 10, 15, 17; (212) 340-4773; ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'': Aug. 31, Sept. 2, 7, 9, 14, 16; (212) 330-7702; all shows, Thursday, Friday and Saturday, 8 p.m.; Sunday 7 p.m.; free; La Plaza Cultural, 9th Street and Avenue C.
HUDSON RIVER WATERFRONT A Feast to Satisfy Appetites For Barbecue and the Blues
You can seek summer riverside relief today at a blues and barbecue blast on the banks of the Hudson River.
The Blues Barbecue and Fireworks Festival is put on by the Hudson River Park Trust, created to design, build and operate a five-mile park along the Hudson River from Battery Park to 59th Street.

Free blues performances will be put on by Guy Davis, Heather (Lil' Mama) Hardy, Roxy Perry, the Christine Santelli Band, Michael Hill's Blues Mob (left) and Not for Nothin'. Barbecue will be sold from restaurants including the Hog Pit, Emily's and Brothers Bar-B-Que. Fireworks will top off the festival.
Blues Barbecue and Fireworks Festival; today, 2 p.m. to 9 p.m.; Pier 84 at 44th Street on the Hudson River; free; (212) 533-7275.
UPPER WEST SIDE A Celebration of the Song Of the Swedish Nightingale
Jenny Lind, the soprano sensation often referred to as the Swedish Nightingale, made her formal operatic debut at age 17 at the Stockholm Royal Theater in 1837.
She was already famous on arrival for her American concert tour, which took place from 1850 to 1852, and was organized and promoted by P. T. Barnum.

''Jenny Lind: The Swedish Nightingale in America'' opens this week at the New-York Historical Society. The exhibition examines the singer's popularity with memorabilia, including paintings, medals and manufactured and homemade goods, culled from the collection of the Historical Society.
The show is presented in conjunction with a consortium of museums and cultural organizations both in and beyond New York.
It includes a concert and lecture at the Museum of the City of New York on Sept. 10 and a daylong festival in Battery Park on Sept. 11.
The image of Lind shown here is dated about 1850; the photographer is unidentified.

The Jenny Lind Festival Exhibition; Tuesday through Oct. 29, daily hours Tuesday through Sunday 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.; The New-York Historical Society, Two West 77th Street, at Central Park West; $5; students and people over 65, $3; children 12 and under, free; (212) 873-3400.
